author: R Vimal Kumar
text:
‘Scaling Pambadumalai’, a full-day trekking expedition organised by Forest Department officials on Sunday involving tribal people to climb the two-km high peak has been carried out with a unique objective.

“We conducted the programme to educate the tribal community the need to preserve in general the peaks, which play an important role in stabilising the ecosystem and bringing rains, and also the conservation of the peaks in Udumalpet forest range that provides habitat for Nilgiri Tahr, an endemic species that faces extinction.

“The tribal people can play a vital role in helping the forest department officials in conservation of ecosystem and give information on intruders who pose a threat to the ecological system”, District Forest Officer A. Periasamy told The Hindu .

The Pambadumalai peak falls in Udumalpet forest range and gives a panoramic view of entire forest cover in the area. As part of the event, a total of 30 people, including forest officials and tribal people, trekked a total distance of 15 km from near Chinnar check-post to reach the peak, which is situated exactly at 2,054 metres above the ground level.
title: Trekking with a unique objective
